message_1:
Consider the topological space (R, T), where R is the set of all real numbers and T is the standard topology on R. 

Let S be the closed interval [0,1]. Determine whether S is a compact set in (R, T).
message_2:
To determine whether S is a compact set in (R, T), we need to show that every open cover of S has a finite subcover. Recall that an open cover of S is a collection of open sets in T such that their union contains S.

Let {U_i} be an arbitrary open cover of S. Since S is a closed interval [0, 1], it is a bounded set. We will use the Heine-Borel theorem, which states that a subset of R is compact if and only if it is closed and bounded. 

S is closed because it contains all its limit points, and it is bounded because it is contained within the interval [0, 1]. Therefore, by the Heine-Borel theorem, S is compact.

Thus, every open cover of S has a finite subcover, and S is a compact set in (R, T).
